user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
```c
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No fragments modify the pointer parameter iter itself. The code only modifies fields of the object pointed to by iter (e.g. ++iter->token.obj_idx and iter->token.obj_id = ...), which is permitted by Rule 17.8. The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token) expands to use &(iter->token) and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken takes a const pointer, so neither the macro nor the inline function modifies the iter pointer. There are no assignments to iter (no iter = ..., ++iter, or similar), and no other expressions that would rebind or alter the pointer parameter itself. Therefore no code fragments require further investigation for Rule 17.8 compliance.
